Class Screen2D

  • java.lang.Object
    • Screen2D

  • public class Screen2D
extends java.lang.Object
    Note the changes to this class for use with the other code in this project. This class encapsulates (hides) the confusion of working with the 2D char array directly elsewhere in our program.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Screen2D()
      A good default size is somewhere close to videographic aspect ratios.
      Screen2D(int width, int height)
      You may want to have more than one output screen to do some of your own graphics as part of your game (for example, maps, or effects).

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void clear()
      This will fill the 2D char array with backtick ` characters (usually under the tilde ~ in the top-left corner of a keyboard).
      void display(int width, int height)
      Actually print the 2D char array to output.
      void drawLine(Point2D first, Point2D second, char stroke)
      Avoids using floating-point arithmetic for a faster drawing of a line.
      char get(int x, int y)
      This method swaps the order of the x and y values for us (so we don't have to swap them everywhere else in our code).
      void set(int x, int y, char c)
      Similar to the get method, but assign a char value to an x and y position in the 2D char array.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • Screen2D

        public Screen2D()
        A good default size is somewhere close to videographic aspect ratios. Keep in mind that each text character is NOT square. Default width is set to 80 chars, and default height is set to 30 chars.

      • Screen2D

        public Screen2D(int width,
                int height)
        You may want to have more than one output screen to do some of your own graphics as part of your game (for example, maps, or effects).
        Parameters:
        width - The number of chars in the horizontal axis of the 2D char array.
        height - The number of chars in the vertical axis of the 2D char array.

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public void clear()
        This will fill the 2D char array with backtick ` characters (usually under the tilde ~ in the top-left corner of a keyboard).

      • get

        public char get(int x,
                int y)
        This method swaps the order of the x and y values for us (so we don't have to swap them everywhere else in our code).
        Parameters:
        x - The horizontal position inside the 2D char array.
        y - The vertical position inside the 2D char array.
        Returns:
        The char value stored in the 2D char array at column x and row y.

      • set

        public void set(int x,
                int y,
                char c)
        Similar to the get method, but assign a char value to an x and y position in the 2D char array.
        Parameters:
        x - The column position in the 2D char array.
        y - The row position in the 2D char array.
        c - The char value to store in the 2D char array.

      • display

        public void display(int width,
                    int height)
        Actually print the 2D char array to output.
        Parameters:
        width - The characters in the 2D char array that will be displayed, along the horizontal axis interval [0, width).
        height - The characters in the 2D char array that will be displayed, along the vertical axis interval [0, height).

      • drawLine

        public void drawLine(Point2D first,
                     Point2D second,
                     char stroke)
        Avoids using floating-point arithmetic for a faster drawing of a line. Feel free to ask me about the math and why it works.
        Parameters:
        first - The start position of the straight line.
        second - The end position of the straight line.
        stroke - The character used to draw the line.
